awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Nanofilters for Selective Gold Extraction
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve gold extraction by improving metal ion capture. Many industries discharge increasing amounts of toxic heavy and valuable metals into different complex water sources. These metals of interest tend to be at trace amounts in water mixtures containing high concentrations of inorganic and organic interferents. It is extremely difficult to extract and concentrate such species in these conditions. This project employs novel hybrid materials to selectively and rapidly extract different toxic, rare and/or valuable metal species at trace concentrations from water in a high-capacity, rapid, cost-effective process. These new materials could impact mining of valuable metals like gold, generating new sustainable supply sources. 

The proposed project is to implement a hybrid nano-porous material into filter devices and evaluate its gold extracting performance under a continuous flow operation typically seen in industry. Although batch adsorption experiments can provide information to initially assess adsorbents, continuous fixed-bed adsorption experiments must be conducted to obtain other crucial information such as breakthrough time, length of mass transfer zone and maximum capacity of the column under those continuous dynamic conditions. Currently, the hybrid materials are synthesized as nanoparticles (between 250 nm and 500 nm), too small to be implemented in a traditional filter device so that the materials must be optimally shaped and structured first to prevent pressure drops and loss of materials in the continuous flow operation. Next, continuous flow experiments will be conducted to study parameters such as column bed length, column bed diameter, adsorbent mass, flow rate and analyte concentration. The project will conduct verification and validation of a model for prototype development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The precision separation of critical metals from complex mixtures is of both environmental and economic significance. Recently, there has been a historic investment and effort in developing novel sustainable technologies to separate and purify these highly valued critical metals. Gold, for example, is an extremely valuable commodity and has significant economic relevance. 

Sunchem’s Nano Filter Technology is based on Metal-organic Framework/Polymer composite materials, which are highly porous and selective for metal capture. In addition, the sustainable process employed at Sunchem replaces inadequate separation technologies that foul easily, lack selectivity, and are environmentally unfriendly, into high value markets such as critical metals, water treatment and energy.

The capture of gold from solids requires three critical steps: 1) leaching of the precious metal into a solution, 2) concentrating the gold ions from the leachate, and 3) reducing the aqueous gold ions to solid gold. However, the conventional approach to achieve extraction and concentration of gold from e-waste is energy intensive and requires highly toxic alkali cyanide, posing risks to operators and degradation to the environment. To overcome these challenges, we employed environmentally friendly and low-toxicity oxidizing agents and organic chelators.

Sunchem’s objective was to engineer the gold selective MOF/Polymer materials into a proof-of-concept gold extracting filter device to demonstrate competitive selectivity and superior performance of our materials under a dynamic continuous flow operation. In Phase I, we were able to structure the powder MOF/Polymer composite material into granules that could be packed into continuous flow column filters. Within the Nano Filter column, the granules showed to be robust and withstand a pressurized system, while retaining the chemical properties that allow for effective gold capture. As such, we demonstrated the Nano Filter to be at technology readiness level (TRL) 3. At this scale, up to 42 weight percent of gold is able to be recovered. We showed that we are able to purify about 2 grams of gold in only one week after processing 100 gallons of water. 

Moreover, the performance of the Nano Filter was modeled using MATLAB to predict breakthrough curves. A preliminary mechanism for Au adsorption was also formulated based on experimental observations. Building upon the milestones achieved in Phase I, we are confident that we can further refine our technology, scale it up, and unlock its full potential for revolutionizing metal extraction and purification processes.

 


Last Modified: 01/11/2024
Modified by: Daniel T Sun

Image
  • Sunchem's Nano Filter technology is capable of concentrating 2 grams of gold, after processing 100 gallons of gold-containing water within 7 days.
    Daniel Sun
    Copyrighted
    Daniel T Sun
    Sunchem's Nano Filter Technology
